title: ‘Thousands of Dollars for Something I Didn’t Do’

last_post.content:
A well-reported story from @kashhill and Ryan Mac about the errors of face recognition technology:

https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/31/technology/facial-recognition-false-arrests.html

As my colleague Nate Wessler says, “This is a chilling reminder of how dangerous face recognition technology is in the hands of police."

But I have a few other thoughts as well.

While the technology in this case is novel, the kafkaesque nature of the penal system is not. This man was arrested and stayed in jail for 6 days and didn't know why. It cost thousands of dollars to get a lawyer, and he missed 6 days of work. He could have been fired, not only missed being paid. That alone for many people would be a crushing economic blow.

And don't miss the inhumanity. Did no one bother to talk to the man and ask, "have you ever been to this state?" Or ask if he could prove he wasn't there when the crime happened, like because he was at work? Or did they just cage him?

The cruelty of the system is a big part of why the tech is so dangerous. You have to fix both.

title: GitHub - cavi-au/Consent-O-Matic: Browser extension that automatically fills out cookie popups based on your preferences

last_post.content:
Consent-O-Matic is a browser extension that auto-responds to all the #GDPR and similar consent popups with optimal user preferences.

Unlike the extension "I don't care about cookies" which just accepts all cookies, Consent-O-Matic clicks the prompts on your behalf to reject most of the cookies. You can also choose what to accept/reject in the preferences.

Available for Firefox, Chrome and others.

I've been using this on Firefox :firefox: for quite sometime now and it works great!

Their Github page has links to official extension stores: https://github.com/cavi-au/Consent-O-Matic#introduction

#AMO link: https://addons.mozilla.org/firefox/addon/consent-o-matic/

#privacy #webextensions #addons #addon #extension #chrome #firefox #safari

title: ChatGPT Has a Big Privacy Problem

last_post.content:
Privacy issues at the heart of ChatGPT are catching up with OpenAI. Since Italy announced a temporary ban on ChatGPT last week, regulators in Ireland, Germany, and France have asked Italy from more information. Canada has opened its own investigation.

At the center of the problems—aside from some smaller issues—is how training data scraped from the internet includes people’s personal information.

In Europe, unlike the US where OpenAI is based, personal data on the open web is still protected by data protection laws. And it seems like OpenAI’s legal justification from scooping everything up isn’t good enough.

But this is also a wider problem. It cuts to the core of all machine learning systems. Training data can’t just be scooped up from the open web, existing ML datasets likely don’t have data protection considerations, and ongoing uses of ML may all be subject to the issues

Read more here: https://www.wired.com/story/italy-ban-chatgpt-privacy-gdpr/

#chatgpt #tech #news #dataprotection #artificialintelligence #technology

title: The unreasonable effectiveness of few-shot learning for machine translation

last_post.content:
For people that say that LLMs "don't really understand" language.

How do you explain this?

"The unreasonable effectiveness of few-shot learning for machine translation" trains a model on text from different languages - NOT explicitly translated. It's never given matching pairs of the same text in two languages.

Just given about 5 example translations on the prompt, the model is then able to match the performance of state of the art specialized translation systems.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.01398

last_post.content:
“Why are autonomous vehicles (henceforth, AVs) still not reliable enough to be widely used? I suspect because driving a car is not a single task, but a task complex, a bundle of many different subtasks with varying inputs. The overall reliability of driving is highly dependent on the performance of those subtasks, and failure in any one of them could lead to overall failure.”

title: FBI Seizes Bot Shop ‘Genesis Market’ Amid Arrests Targeting Operators, Suppliers – Krebs on Security

last_post.content:
Breaking, exclusive: Several domain names tied to Genesis Market, a bustling cybercrime store that sold access to passwords and other data stolen from millions of computers infected with malicious software, were seized by the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) today.

Sources tell KrebsOnsecurity the domain seizures coincided with "dozens" of arrests in the United States and abroad targeting those who allegedly operated the service, as well as suppliers who continuously fed Genesis Market with freshly-stolen data.

https://krebsonsecurity.com/2023/04/fbi-seizes-bot-shop-genesis-market-amid-arrests-targeting-operators-suppliers/

How often do you get to say it? Progress! NPR will not air Trump live if he speaks about his indictment today, a small win for common sense. (Some might say microscopic.)

But if you click and listen to NPR's executive editor, Terry Samuel, this may be the closest we get to NPR conceding that its Trump coverage 2016 to now didn't work because it tried to use normal tools and assumptions. To me that's significant, and it almost never happens.

https://www.npr.org/2023/04/03/1167856064/a-peek-behind-the-curtain-of-nprs-coverage-of-trumps-indictment

#uspol #journalism #npr

If you've seen me give a talk lately, it probably included this 1-slide, hot-take version of an in-progress paper - we talk about 'novices' a lot in data visualization research, but who do we (and *don't* we) implicitly refer to in those papers?

Well it's no longer in-progress and this slide-edit is wonderful to make - 🏆 a Best Paper Award at CHI 2023! Huge shoutout to @AJBurns, who 1st authored and deserves all the credit! 🥳

Preprint: https://www.alyxburns.com/files/preprint_2022_WhoDoWeMeanByVisNovices.pdf

Although their devices were passcode-protected, “they [Services Australia] went through all our WhatsApp and Facebook messages. And they actually talked, during their investigation, about what was said in them,” she added.

title: Pythia: A Suite for Analyzing Large Language Models Across Training and Scaling

last_post.content:
RT @BlancheMinerva@twitter.com

Have you ever wanted to do an experiment on LLMs and found that none of the existing model suites met your needs? At @AiEleuther@twitter.com we got tired of this happening and so designed a model suite that centers enabling scientific research as its primary goal

https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01373

title: Study: SARS-CoV-2, the virus causing COVID-19, can alter genome structure of our cells - Anesthesiology, Critical Care and Pain Medicine

last_post.content:
... unknown pathogen causes during an infection is a *lower bound* to the actual harms. It's not even centered on the expectation value, because you can expect to learn more about the harms in the future.

People do not understand this intentional bias in scientific research. And people make risk decisions around a *lower bound* for risk, not around *expected value* of risk.

One data point about underestimating COVID harms:

https://med.uth.edu/anesthesiology/2023/03/23/study-sars-cov-2-the-virus-causing-covid-19-can-alter-genome-structure-of-our-cells/

title: TPU v4: An Optically Reconfigurable Supercomputer for Machine Learning with Hardware Support for Embeddings

last_post.content:
TPU v4: An Optically Reconfigurable Supercomputer for Machine Learning with Hardware Support for Embeddings

title: SoK: On the Impossible Security of Very Large Foundation Models

last_post.content:
On the large AI models, this preprint synthesises what we know so far https://arxiv.org/abs/2209.15259

In short: it is mathematically impossible to have AIs combining the following properties:

1) High number of parameters
2) Robustness to poisoning (e.g. fake data)
3) Privacy-preserving

title: "Stochastic parrot" is a misleading metaphor for LLMs

last_post.content:

must reside in Boston

The vast, vast majority of attempts to build communities online (open source projects, wikis, subreddits, etc.) don't really go anywhere. Very few get more than a few contributions from a few contributors. Why do so many fail?

https://doi.org/10.1093/jcmc/zmad002

title: This Questionable Study Caught Fire in Anti-Vaccine Circles. How Did It Get Through Peer Review?

last_post.content: SCOOP: A peer-reviewed study claimed that as many as 278,000 people have died from COVID vaccines. It went viral in anti-vaccine circles, and also drew fierce criticism (one expert called "among the worst things I've ever seen published"). Now it's in the process of being retracted, over the author's objections. https://www.chronicle.com/article/this-questionable-study-caught-fire-in-anti-vaccine-circles-how-did-it-get-through-peer-review

RT @AlphaSignalAI@twitter.com

Big News! Meta just released Segment Anything, a new AI model that can "cut out" any object, in any image/video, with a single click.

The model is designed and trained to be promptable, so it can transfer zero-shot to new image distributions and tasks.

https://segment-anything.com/

🐦🔗: https://twitter.com/AlphaSignalAI/status/1643637715571732483

title: GitHub - gdbassett/slightly-more-than-minimal-blockly: attempt to use blockly with wasm-r

last_post.content:
Not much, but it's a start: #RStats #WebR #blockly. **BIG** thanks to @hrbrmstr. I wouldn't have made it this far w/o him.

(This has been something I've wanted to do for years, but couldn't until #WebR. Imagine if you could load your own breach data as VERIS, filter/mutate it to get the subset you want, then analyze it. All in the browser w/o knowing #rstats

Still *very* early, but the PoC works!

EDIT: It's not pretty, but I've shared the code at https://github.com/gdbassett/slightly-more-than-minimal-blockly.

Book release!! 📘🥳

"Deep Learning and Scientific Computing with R torch" by Sigrid Keydana

Freely available online, this book introduces torch basics, shares deep-learning use cases & shows how to use torch for general topics, such as matrix computations & the Fourier Transform.

Blog post about the release: https://blogs.rstudio.com/ai/posts/2023-04-05-deep-learning-scientific-computing-r-torch/

e-book: https://taylorfrancis.com/books/mono/10.1201/9781003275923/deep-learning-scientific-computing-torch-sigrid-keydana

Order a print copy: https://routledge.com/Deep-Learning-and-Scientific-Computing-with-R-torch/Keydana/p/book/9781032231396

Free online edition: https://skeydan.github.io/Deep-Learning-and-Scientific-Computing-with-R-torch/

title: Private Planes and Luxury Yachts Aren’t Just Toys for the Ultrawealthy. They’re Also Huge Tax Breaks.

last_post.content:
How the Ultrarich Claim Huge Tax Deductions on Their Private Jets and Luxury Yachts
--
If you only read one thing from this latest Secret IRS Files entry, make it this bit about the wealthy Florida man whose 180-foot #yacht is also a "business" that has let him claim millions in #IncomeTax deductions:

#Taxes #IRS #Wealth #Boats #Planes #PrivateJets

https://www.propublica.org/article/private-jets-yachts-wealthy-tax-deductions-irs-files?utm_medium=social&utm_source=mastodon&utm_campaign=mastodon-post
Using mmap to make LLaMA load faster - https://justine.lol/mmap/

A preprint that I've been working on for quite some time with the brilliant @raphaelmilliere is now available on ArXiv: The Vector Grounding Problem -
https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01481

In a nutshell, we argue that some large pretrained #ai models, especially those fine-tuned with #RLHF, have the features required to have internal representations and outputs imbued with intrinsic meaning.

We show this is in 3 steps. First, we argue that the traditional Symbol Grounding Problem for classical AI (...)

title: Klaus Teuber, Creator of the Board Game Catan, Dies at 70

last_post.content:
What a beautiful quote and life lesson from Klaus Teuber, inventor of Catan:

“There may have been a good balance between strategy and luck,” he said. “For example, roulette is only about luck, and chess is all about strategies. However, if you win in Catan, you think, ‘My strategy was good,’ and when you lose, you might think, ‘I was just out of luck.’ This is the same as life.”

#boardgames #catan
